Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India Bismuth is renowned for its exceptional safety, highlighted by numerous examples demonstrating its low toxicity. Considering this, we present a novel, active, and reusable heterogeneous bismuth catalyst (Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3) for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to aryl amines using molecular hydrogen. The Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized through a simple impregnation method followed by pyrolysis at 700°C, for 2 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The physicochemical properties of fresh and spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were comprehensively characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The bismuth content in the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was estimated by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance and selectivity in reducing a wide variety of nitroarenes to their corresponding aryl amines, achieving good to excellent yields (36 examples). Furthermore, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was applied to the selective hydrogenation of nitro groups in three commercially available drugs. Additionally, five pharmaceutical intermediates, including linezolid, Norfloxacin, Carbamazepine, paracetamol, and tizanidine, were synthesized up to a ∼1 g scale with a quantitative yield, showcasing the catalyst activity and selectivity. Further, the reaction mechanism was elucidated by tracking the intermediates (through GC-FID & GC-MS) and employing Density Functional Theory (DFT). Notably, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is stable, recovered, and reused for four cycles without losing significant activity and selectivity. Graphical Abstract Keywords Bismuth Hydrogenation Nitroarenes Amines Active pharmaceutical intermediates DFT studies Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Green chemistry is revolutionizing chemical manufacturing processes by using non-toxic reactants and solvents, reducing toxic transition-metal catalysts, enhancing reaction efficiency with greener additives, and developing eco-friendly synthetic pathways with high atom economies to achieve the sustainability goals of modern chemistry [1–4]. Amines represent a crucial and extensively sought-after category of chemicals, serving as essential components in various chemical applications [5–8]. They are integral to formulating dyes, pigments, polymers, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, solvents, fine chemicals, and various other products, highlighting their versatile role in diverse industries [9–11]. For instance, Morphine and Demerol are examples of amines employed as analgesics for pain relief, while Novocain serves as an anesthetic [12–14]. Ephedra, a common decongestant, also falls under the category of amines. Imbruvica, Xalkori, Calquence, Trajenta, and numerous other drugs based on amines are currently among the top 200 best-selling pharmaceuticals [15]. Amines are also integral in manufacturing azodyes, nylon, and various chemicals for crop protection, medication, and water purification [16]. The synthesis of amines often involves the reduction of nitro compounds using catalysts, using homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts [17–21]. The reusability and recyclability of homogeneous catalysts pose significant challenges. To address these issues, heterogeneous catalysts based on precious metals such as palladium (Pd), rhodium (Rh), gold (Au), and silver (Ag) have been developed for the chemoselective hydrogenation of arenes with a variety of functional groups [7,22]. The use of noble metals in industrial applications is challenged by their scarcity, toxicity, and high cost, which pose significant safety, occupational health, and sustainability concerns. In addition, Chemical industries face numerous challenges when converting nitro compounds to various amines, including poor selectivity and the unintended loss of functional groups, particularly halogens -Cl, -Br, and -I. Further, the disposal of spent catalysts and effluents complicates these issues. Traditionally, the hydrogenation of organic compounds has been achieved either through direct hydrogenation using molecular hydrogen gas [23–28] or via catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) [29–34], which involves transferring hydrogen from various hydrogen sources. Recently, significant progress has been made in developing non-noble-metal-based heterogeneous catalysts for hydrogenation reactions [35–51]. Even metal-free catalysts have also been reported for the reduction of nitro compounds [52]. The Beller research group developed nanocatalysts based on earth-abundant cobalt and iron for the selective hydrogenation of nitroarenes with various functional groups [53,54]. Building on their pioneering work, numerous other researchers have explored the use of 3d transition metals for the chemoselective reduction of nitroarenes [55–66]. On the other hand, Bismuth, although grouped with heavy and toxic metals on the periodic table, stands out for its remarkable safety record, underscored by numerous examples showcasing its low toxicity [67–73]. For example, Pepto-Bismol serves as a widely recognized over-the-counter remedy for stomach disorders, and bismuth oxychloride is utilized safely to provide a silvery sheen to cosmetics and personal care products, suggesting its potential for safe chemical applications [74–77]. Investigations into bismuth-based compounds also cover many areas, including electron conductivity, thermal conductivity, thermoelectricity, piezoelectricity, magnetism, optics, electromagnetics, pharmaceutical applications, and catalytic behaviors in organic synthesis [78,79]. Due to the low toxicity of bismuth, there are several organic conversions involving hydrogenation, oxidation, and carbon-carbon bond formation were studied using bismuth-based catalysts [78–89]. For example, bismuth-based oxidation catalysts, such as bismuth vanadate (BiVO4), have shown promise as catalysts for water oxidation in photoelectrochemical cells used for solar fuel generation [90]. Bismuth-tungstate catalysts have been investigated for their photocatalytic properties and are used in processes such as pollutant degradation, water splitting, and CO2 reduction [91–94]. Bismuth catalysts also have shown potential in selective transformations, such as converting CO2 and biomass-derived compounds to value-added chemicals [94–98]. Bismuth(III) triflate has been employed in various organic transformations like Friedel-Crafts acylation & alkylation reactions, alcohol and amine fictionalization, C-C & C-N bond formation, and Ring-opening Reactions [86,99]. Nevertheless, a few documented transfer hydrogenation reactions have utilized low-valent bismuth catalysts ( Scheme 1). For instance, in 2014, the application of bismuth nanoparticles for reducing nitroaromatics in the presence of sodium borohydrate was reported [89]. In 2019, Cornella J. and their team introduced a homogeneous bismuth complex to reduce nitro-arenes and azo-arenes, utilizing ammonia-borane as the transfer hydrogenation agent [33]. Most recently (2023), Lahcini M. and their team contributed to this field by reporting the successful use of bismuth nanoparticles supported on biobased chitosan as sustainable catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of nitroarenes using sodium borohydride [82]. While bismuth-based catalysts are gaining significant attention in the field of catalysis, there is a notable absence of reports on their use for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes with molecular hydrogen. This may be attributed to the greater focus of research on d-block elements, which has resulted in less attention being given to p-block elements, particularly bismuth [100]. In this context, we introduce a novel and sustainable heterogeneous bismuth-based catalyst (Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3) for the chemoselective hydrogenation of various nitroarenes, including commercially available nitro-based drugs, using molecular hydrogen. We successfully synthesized five pharmaceutical intermediates: linezolid, norfloxacin, carbamazepine, paracetamol, and tizanidine on a ∼1 g scale with quantitative yields. The reaction mechanism was investigated by tracking intermediates using GC-FID and GC-MS and employing Density Functional Theory (DFT). Remarkably, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated stability and could be recovered and reused efficiently. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All reagents employed in the experiments were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, TCI, India, and used without further purification. Unless otherwise mentioned, all reactions were carried out using 25 mL and 50-mL stainless steel high-pressure autoclaves (Fig. S1). 2.2 General procedure for the preparation of bismuth-based catalysts The catalyst synthesis involves an impregnation technique followed by pyrolysis [101–103]. Initially, bismuth nitrate and 1,10-phenanthroline solution were prepared by dissolving a required amount of Bi(NO3)2•5 H2O in an aqueous HNO3 solution (1 %), and 1,10-phenanthroline (3 equivalent) in H2O separately. Subsequently, each solution was individually added dropwise to various supports such as γ-alumina, Silica-Alumina, and ZSM-5, which was then stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Upon completion of the stirring process, excess water was removed by heating, and the resulting solid material was subjected to overnight drying at 100°C in an oven. Finally, the material was calcined under the N2 atmosphere at 700°C for 2 h with a 3°C/min ramping. The resulting catalysts were labeled Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3, Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5. 2.3 Synthesis of Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Initially, bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (0.116 g) was added to a 10 mL solution containing aqueous 1.0 % HNO3, and stirred for 30 minutes to get a clear solution. This solution was then slowly added dropwise to 0.95 g of γ-Al2O3 support. Concurrently, a solution of 0.129 g of 1,10-phenanthroline in 10 mL distilled water was prepared and added to the mixture of bismuth nitrate and γ-Al2O3. After stirring for 4 h, the mixture was gradually heated to 100–110°C for 4 h, followed by overnight drying at the same temperature. The final step involved calcination at 700°C for 2 hours under N2, forming the catalyst Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3. The synthesis of the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst is outlined in Scheme 2. 2.4 General procedure for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes A high-pressure tubular autoclave (25 mL) was charged with nitroarene (∼0.5 mmol) along with t-BuOH (2–3 mL) and Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst (25–35 mg). The reactor was sealed and purged four times with nitrogen, followed by three times with hydrogen to remove the air from the reactor. Next, the reactor is pressurized with hydrogen gas in the range of 10–25 bar. Then, the reaction mixture was stirred at the desired temperature (100°C to 150°C) for the required time (18 h to 36 h). Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was carefully cooled in a water bath until it reached room temperature, ensuring the safe release of remaining hydrogen. The Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst was separated through simple filtration, washed thrice with ethyl acetate and ethanol, and dried under vacuum at 60°C. The crude product was analyzed using GCMS. Additionally, selective reaction mixtures were concentrated under a vacuum using a rotary evaporator and then purified via column chromatography, utilizing a solvent mixture of hexane: ethyl acetate or hexane: chloroform. Finally, the purified product was analyzed using GC-MS and NMR techniques. 2.5 Procedure for gram-scale reactions A stainless steel high-pressure tubular autoclave with a 50 mL capacity was filled with approximately 1 g of nitroarene in ∼10 mL of t-BuOH alongside a Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst (2.4 mol% Bi). Then, the autoclave was sealed and purged with N2 and then with H2 gases repeatedly 3 times to eliminate any residual air. Subsequently, the autoclave was pressurized with 10–25 bar H2 as needed and kept for stirring in an oil bath at temperatures from 100ºC to 130ºC for 18–36 h. Upon completion of the reaction time, the autoclave was gradually cooled to room temperature using a water bath, and excess H2 pressure was cautiously released. The catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture through simple filtration. The resulting crude product mixture underwent purification via column chromatography using a mixture of hexane and ethyl acetate in an appropriate ratio as the mobile phase. Finally, the purified product was analyzed using NMR and GC-MS techniques. 2.6 DFT studies Periodic DFT calculations were conducted using the DMol3 software implemented in Material Studio (Biovia, San Diego) [104–106]. The GGA-PBE exchange-correlation function was applied for all the DFT calculations [104–106]. Localized double-numerical basis sets with d-functions (DND) were applied for these calculations and accompanied the empirical dispersion correction pioneered by Tkatchenko-Scheffler (TS). The electron-core interaction was described with Effective Core Potential. Fermi smearing of 0.005 Hartree was employed for improved computational performance. Convergence criteria were set at 2 × 10−5 Ha for energy, 4 × 10−3 Ha nm−1 for forces, and 5 × 10−4 nm for displacement. All the DFT calculations were performed in a spin-polarized set-up. A four-layered Bismuth (202) surface was modeled by cleaving Bismuth bulk in the 202 directions. For all the calculations, the bottom two layers were fixed, and the top two layers and adsorbates were allowed to relax. To obtain realistic thermodynamics of the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline on the Bi (202) surface, considering the critical role of reaction temperature, Gibbs free energies at 373 K were obtained using the formula: G = E – TS ----( 1 ). G represents the Gibbs free energy, E denotes the reaction energy, and T & S indicates the temperature and entropy. Entropy for reactant and product species was obtained from the NIST Chemistry Web book. Reaction energies (Ereaction) for elementary reaction steps were calculated as the difference between final (EFS) and initial (EIS) state energies: Ereaction = EIS - EFS ----( 2 ). Meanwhile, reaction-free energy (Greaction) is calculated as the difference between final (GFS) and initial (GIS) state-free energies: Greaction = GIS - GFS- ----( 3 ). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening and optimization of reaction parameters The catalytic activity of novel Bi-based catalysts was meticulously assessed for the selective nitro reduction of 4-nitroanisole (1a) to 4-methoxyaniline (1b), using molecular hydrogen. The comprehensive results of these experiments, highlighting the activity and selectivity of the catalysts, have been carefully compiled and presented in Table 1. The selection of 4-nitroanisole as a model substrate is attributed to its suitability for smooth monitoring of catalyst activity and selectivity regarding preferential hydrogenation of nitro moiety over competing reactions such as C-O hydrogenolysis and ring hydrogenation. Initially, we commenced the reaction without any catalyst, and no discernible progress was observed (Table 1, entry 1). Notably, both the γ-Al2O3 support and 1,10-phenanthroline exhibited completely inactive in reducing 4-nitroanisole (1a) to 4-methoxyaniline (Table 1, entries 2 & 3). This result suggests the essential role of active metal within the catalyst material for effective nitro reduction. Subsequently, we turned our attention to employing the reaction with Bi(NO3)2•5 H2O, Bi(NO3)2•5 H2O/1,10-phenanthroline, and the Bi(NO3)2•5 H2O/1,10-phenanthroline impregnated on γ-Al2O3 (without calcination). Unfortunately, this led to significantly poor conversion of 4-nitroanisole and selectivity towards 4-methoxyaniline, as evident in Table 1, entries 4–6. To our delight, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited excellent performance, achieved 99 % conversion of 4-nitroanisole and 99 % selectivity towards 4-methoxyaniline at 120°C for 18 h, under 10 bar H2 pressure, with the desired product isolated in 97 % yield (Table 1 , entry 8). Further, we explored the catalytic activity of Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts. Despite achieving complete conversion of p-nitroanisole with both catalysts, the selectivity of 4-methoxyaniline was only 82 % and 88 %, respectively. In addition to the desired product, notable quantities of C-O hydrogenolysis byproduct, specifically 4-aminophenol (1c), and a small proportion of ring hydrogenated products (1d, 1e) were identified (Table 1, entries 9–10). Additionally, to understand the impact of nitrogen doping in the catalyst material, we synthesized the Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst without adding 1,10-phenanthroline and assessed its catalytic activity. However, this resulted in only 52 % conversion of 4-nitroanisole with 85 % selectivity for 4-methoxyaniline, accompanied by side products (Table 1, entry 7). Further, the air calcined Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows only 20 % 4-nitroanisole conversion and 10 % 4-methoxyaniline selectivity (Table 1, entry 11). Based on the initial screening results of catalysts (Table 1), it is evident that the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has exceptional catalytic activity and selectivity in converting p-nitroanisole to 4-methoxyaniline (Table 1, entry 8). Therefore, this catalyst has been selected to explore the impact of reaction parameters such as temperature, time, and H2 pressure. We began investigating the temperature-dependent dynamics of our reaction from 30°C to 120°C, while maintaining a constant hydrogen pressure of 10 bar (Table S1). Initial attempts at the extremely low temperature (30°C) yielded only a 10 % conversion of p-nitro anisole, yet the product selectivity remained at 99 % (Table S1, entry 1). When we increased the reaction temperature to 60°C, conversion increased significantly to 52 % while product selectivity remained unchanged (Table S1, entry 2). Further, increasing the temperature to 90°C, the p-nitroanisole conversion significantly improved to 79 % (Table S1, entry 3). Finally, at the optimized reaction temperature (120°C), a 99 % conversion of p-nitroanisole and 99 % selectivity for 4-methoxyaniline (Table S1, entry 4). Next, we evaluated the influence of reaction time on our benchmark reaction; we performed the experiments from 6 h to 24 h (Table S2). After a 6 h reaction time, we achieved a 38 % conversion of p-nitroanisole and 99 % selectivity for 4-methoxyaniline (Table S2, entry 1). After 12 h and 18 h of reaction time, we obtained 61 % and 86 % p-nitroanisole conversion, respectively, with the requisite 99 % product selectivity in both cases (Table S2, entries 2–3). The highest (99 %) p-nitroanisole conversion and 4-methoxyaniline selectivity were effectively obtained after 24 h of reaction time (Table S2, entry 4). After exploring the influence of temperature and time, we delved into the impact of hydrogen pressure on the reaction (Table S3). Employing low hydrogen pressure (5 bar) led to a 48 % conversion of p-nitroanisole with 99 % selectivity for the intended product (Table S3, entry 1). However, increasing the pressure to 10 bar maximized both p-nitroanisole conversion and 4-methoxyaniline selectivity at 99 % (Table S3, entry 2). Subsequent increases in hydrogen pressure had no significant influence on p-nitroanisole conversion or 4-methoxyaniline selectivity (Table S3, entry 3). Our attention then turned towards selecting an appropriate solvent, considering both polar and non-polar solvents under optimal reaction conditions (120ºC for 24 h under 10 bar H2 pressure) (Table S4). To initiate the experiment, we first evaluated t-BuOH as the solvent, which displayed remarkable activity and selectivity for 4-methoxyaniline with a conversion of > 99 % for p-nitroanisole (Table S4, entry 1). However, upon transitioning to IPA and THF:H2O solvents, although the conversion rate remained unchanged (>99 %), the product selectivity decreased to 78 % and 93 %, respectively (Table S4, entries 2–3). Further experimentation with methanol and ethanol as solvents revealed reduced selectivity, yielding only 58 % and 89 % for 4-methoxyaniline, attributed to the formation of some side products (Table S4, entries 4–5). Conversely, employing ethyl acetate and acetonitrile as solvents resulted in improved conversion rates (65 % and 63 %, respectively) with product selectivity exceeding 91 % and > 99 % (Table S4 , entries 6–7). Finally, using non-polar solvents such as n-heptane and decane led to a significant decrease in the conversion of p-nitroanisole to 33 % and 25 %, respectively (Table S4 , entries 8–9). All these findings indicate that the catalytic activity and selectivity of Bi-based catalysts are contingent upon the electronic, chemical, and physical properties of both bismuth particles and the catalyst support materials. Subsequent sections provide a detailed discussion of the comprehensive catalyst characterization. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts Comprehensive analytical techniques were employed to characterize a series of novel Bi-based catalysts, including Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (fresh), Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (spent), Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, Bi-NC/ZSM-5, and Bi/γ-Al2O3. The characterization methods including inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), N2 adsorption-desorption, Raman analysis, H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Collectively, these techniques provided detailed insights into the catalyst composition, structure, and morphology of the catalysts. This holistic characterization approach facilitated the establishment of correlations between the unique structural properties and catalytic activity. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (Fresh), and Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (Spent), Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1. The Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (Fresh), and Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts exhibit the diffracted peaks on the 2-theta scale at 27.9°, 31.8°, 32.7°, 46.2°, 47.0°, 54.2°, 55.7°, and 57.7°, which belong to (201), (002), (220), (222), (400), (203), (213), and (402) crystalline planes of Bi2O3 with tetragonal crystal system (β-phase) (JCPDS Card No. 00–078–1793) [107–109]. In addition to these peaks, the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (Fresh) catalyst shows the diffracted peaks at 27.15°, 37.9°, 39.8°, and 48.7°, identified as (012), (104), (110), and (202) planes of metallic bismuth (Bi(0)) with rhombohedral crystal system (JCPDS Card No. 00–044–1246) (Fig. 1b) [110–113]. On the other hand, Bi/γ-Al2O3 displays (110) and (202) planes, while Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts exhibit only (202) planes of metallic bismuth in the catalyst materials (Fig. 1a and d). After the reaction, the spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrates a similar diffraction pattern to the fresh Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, retaining diffracted peaks of metallic Bi and β-Bi2O3 phase, indicating structural integrity during the reaction (Fig. 1c) [100,114]. However, the Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalyst lacks metallic Bi and β-Bi2O3 peaks, presumably due to the dominance of ZSM-5 support peaks (Fig. 1e). The N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was performed to investigate the structural and textural properties of γ-Al2O3, Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (Fresh), Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (Spent), Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts. The corresponding isotherms, pore distribution, and properties are shown in Fig. 2(i)-(ii), and Table S5. The γ-Al2O3 support, Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (fresh), Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (spent), Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst materials exhibited type-IV isotherms with hysteresis loops, indicating their mesoporous nature (Fig. 2(i) a-e). In contrast, the Bi-NC/ZSM-5 displayed a type-I isotherm, suggesting the presence of micropores in the catalyst (Fig. 2(i) f). The γ-Al2O3 support has a BET surface area of 263.5 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.87 cm3/g, with an average pore diameter of 13.2 nm (Table S5 , entry 1). However, after the loading of Bi2O3 nanoparticles, the BET surface area of the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst decreased to 235.8 m2/g, with pore volumes of 0.63 cm3/g and an average pore diameter of 10.8 nm (Table S5 , entry 2). This decrease in surface area and pore volume could be attributed to blockage of the pores by the deposition of Bi2O3 nanoparticles into the pores of γ-Al2O3 support. Remarkably, after the reaction, there were no significant changes in the surface area (220.3 m2/g), pore volume (0. 52 cm3/g), and pore diameter (9.2 nm) of the spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, indicating retention of structural and textural properties of the catalyst during the reaction (Table S5 , entry 3). In addition, the Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst without adding nitrogen exhibited a BET surface area of 246.6 m2/g, with pore volume and pore diameters of 0.70 cm3/g and 11.8 nm (Table S5 , entry 4). Furthermore, Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts possessed surface areas of 223.3 m2/g and 228.5 m2/g, along with pore volumes of 0.49 cm3/g and 0.20 cm3/g, and pore diameters of 8.8 nm and 2.5 nm, respectively (Table S5 , entry 5 and 6). The X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) technique was employed to find elements' elemental composition and oxidation states within fresh and spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The corresponding spectra are presented in Fig. 3. The survey scans XPS spectrums of a fresh and spent active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, indicating the presence of four elements: bismuth (Bi), nitrogen (N), carbon (C), and oxygen (O), as depicted in Fig. S2-S3 of the Supporting Information. The N1s spectra for both the fresh and spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst show five distinct peaks with specific binding energies at 397.4 eV, 398.5 eV, 400.5 eV, 404.4 eV, and 405.5 eV (Fig. 3(i) a and b). The energy band visualized at 397.4 eV due to the contribution of Bi−Nx moiety, suggesting the direct interaction between nitrogen atoms and bismuth particles [88]. The nitrogen species identified include pyridinic-N at 398.50 eV and pyrrolic-N at 400.56 eV, characteristic peaks commonly found in nitrogen-doped materials [88]. Additionally, two energy bands at 404.4 eV and 405.5 eV were likely indicative of N-oxides [88]. The deconvoluted Bi 4 f XPS spectra (Fig. 3 (ii) a and b) of both fresh and spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst display the two binding energies centered at 156.3 eV and 161.8 eV and are attributed to metallic bismuth (Bi(0)), while two significant peaks observed at 157.9 eV and 163.1 eV are associated with bismuth in + 3 oxidation state (Bi2O3). This suggests the coexistence of bismuth in both zero and + 3 oxidation states within the catalyst materials, consistent with the XRD findings. However, the binding energies are lower than those reported in the literature, attributed to the direct interaction between N-atoms and Bi/Bi2O3 nanoparticles[114]. Furthermore, the high-resolution C1s spectrum (Fig. S4 (iii) a and b) was deconvoluted into three primary peaks at 284.6 eV, 285.5 eV, and 287.4 eV. The dominant peak at 284.6 eV was attributed to sp2/sp3 hybridized carbon, while the energy peak at 285.5 eV was ascribed to sp2 hybridized carbon in conjunction with nitrogen [96]. Additionally, the minor peak at 287.4 eV indicated the presence of -CO interactions. Similarly, the O 1 s core level XPS spectrum (Fig. S4 (iv), a and b) could be resolved into three peaks. The binding energy displayed at 529.1 eV corresponds to the oxygen atoms bound to Bi [97]. The appearance of two additional energy bands at 530.0 eV and 531.8 eV is attributed to the oxygen, existing as −CO and −O−CO/C−OH forms within the catalyst material [98]. The energy bands corresponding to N-oxides were detected in the N1s spectrum but were not apparent in the O1s spectrum, possibly due to its lower resolution. XPS analysis reveals that binding energy positions of Bi 4 f, N 1 s, C 1 s, and O 1 s remain unchanged in the spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, indicating that the initial composition and oxidation states are preserved in the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst during the reaction. HR-TEM analysis was performed to examine the morphology of the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and the corresponding TEM images are shown in Fig. 4. The HR-TEM image reveals irregularly shaped bismuth particles with distinct lattice fringe d-spacing values of 0.326 nm and 0.320 nm, which correspond to the (012) plane of rhombohedral metallic bismuth (Bi(0)) and the (201) plane of Bi2O3 particles, respectively, and are in good agreement with the XRD and XPS results (Fig. 4 c). The edges of the particles contained amorphous organic carbon. The SAED pattern of the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows diffusive rings, indicating an amorphous nature of the catalyst (Fig. 4d). Furthermore, the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) investigation reveals the presence of Al, O, C, N, and Bi elements in the catalyst, which overlap each other (Fig. 4e-j). Fig. S5 in supporting information shows the TEM images of the spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, showing no significant morphological or structural changes following the reaction. However, some aggregation of bismuth particles was observed. The reduction behavior of Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts are evaluated by H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis ( Fig. 5). All catalysts displayed the stepwise reduction of Bi2O3 to metallic Bi [115]. However, some significant differences exist in the TPR profile of all four catalysts. The active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed initial hydrogen consumption peaks between 300°C and 550°C, with Tmax at 483°C and 530°C (Fig. 5b), indicating the reduction of surface oxygen atoms of Bi2O3. Conversely, the high-temperature range peaks between 600°C and 800°C, signifying the reduction of bulk oxygen atoms. In contrast, the Bi/γ-Al2O3 and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited surface oxygen reduction peaks in the temperature range of 240°C to 550°C (Fig. 5b & d). The bulk oxygen reduction peak appeared at temperatures ranging from 530°C to 750°C (Fig. 5 a and d). The shift of oxygen reduction peaks to lower temperatures could be attributed to weak metal-support interactions in these catalysts due to the weak binding of Bi2O3 species to the Al2O3 support. The Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst showed a similar reduction pattern, with the predominant reduction peak observed in the temperature range of 350°C to 600°C (Fig. 5c). The H2-TPR results indicate that the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited reduction peaks at higher temperatures than the other catalysts. This suggests a strong interaction between the nitrogen atoms and the Bi2O3 particles, making it more challenging to reduce and leading to higher reduction temperatures. Next, we evaluated the acidic characteristics of Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts by NH3-TPD analysis with NH3 as a probe molecule, and the results are outlined in Table 2 and illustrated in Fig. 6. The desorption peaks of NH3 served as indicators of the acidic strength sites in the catalysts, which could be categorized into three types: weak acidic sites, moderate acidic sites, and strong acidic sites. All catalysts demonstrate NH3 desorption peaks in the 120–350°C, 350–600°C, and beyond 600°C temperature range, suggesting that all catalysts have weak, moderate, and strong acidic sites on their surface (Fig. 6. a-d). However, the quantity of acidic sites varied among the catalysts. The Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst displayed the highest number of acidic sites (0.210 mmol/g), with weak acidic sites being more prevalent than moderate and strong acidic sites. Following this, the Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalyst showed higher acidity (0.120 mmol/g) compared to Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 (0.090 mmol/g) and Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3 (0.088 mmol/g) catalysts (Table 2). This heightened acidity in the Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can be attributed to the absence of nitrogen, which would typically reduce the acidity of the catalyst [116–118]. Thermogravimetric analysis was employed to investigate the thermal stability of Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3, Bi/γ-Al2O3, Bi-NC/SiO2-Al2O3, and Bi-NC/ZSM-5 catalysts and the corresponding TGA curves are depicted in Fig. S6. The TGA experiments were conducted within the 25–1200°C temperature range, with a ramping rate of 10°C/m under a nitrogen atmosphere. The initial TGA curve revealed a 10 wt% weight loss between 30 and 100°C for all catalysts, attributed to the loss of lattice-held water molecules from the catalyst surface. Notably, all catalysts exhibited stability up to 750°C, beyond which a weight loss of approximately 5–15 wt% was observed for all catalysts. The comprehensive analysis of XRD, XPS, and TEM revealed that bismuth exhibits both zero and + 3 oxidation states within the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and the presence of interactions between nitrogen atoms and bismuth particles, contributing to enhanced stability of the bismuth species and an increased electron density surrounding bismuth particles. Consequently, these factors collectively increase the catalyst activity and selectivity. Further, the results of catalytic screening experiments (Table 1) indicate that when calcined in air, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits notably poor activity and selectivity. This observation suggests that the presence of bismuth in its zero oxidation state (Bi(0)) is likely accountable for the exceptional activity and selectivity observed in the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Furthermore, aside from the oxidation state, the acidity profile of the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst emerges as a pivotal determinant influencing both the conversion rates and selectivity outcomes, thereby underscoring the multifaceted factors governing the catalytic behavior of this system. 3.3 Catalytic activity of Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes An extensive examination of the reaction's capabilities and constraints was conducted and outlined in Schemes 3–5, under optimized reaction conditions. Initially, our focus centered on evaluating the effectiveness of catalysts in converting various simple nitroarenes, including monoaromatic, polyaromatic, and heteroaromatic nitroarenes. Substrates are primarily chosen based on their relevance to industrial applications, our previous work, and existing literature, to expand the applicability of the catalysts[61,119]. Our experimental setup included nitroarenes (0.5 mmol), a Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst (25 mg, ∼2.40 mol% Bi), H2 (10–15 bar), t-BuOH (2 mL), and temperatures from 100°C-130°C, with reaction times from 24 to 36 h. Remarkably, all compounds tested underwent selective hydrogenation, yielding the corresponding amines without any discernible side products, except a few nitroarenes with halogen substituents. The transformations of nitrobenzene, 2,6-dimethyl nitrobenzene, 3,5-dimethyl nitrobenzene, and 2-ethyl nitrobenzene (Scheme 3 , entries 1–4) were highly effective, yielded between 77 % and 92 % and demonstrating complete selectivity. Continued investigation extended to nitrobenzenes with halogen substitutions (F, Cl, Br, and I) at different positions on the aromatic rings (Scheme 3 , entries 5–12), resulting in yields ranging from 48 % to 93 %. Nevertheless, chloro, bromo, and iodo-substituted nitro compounds displayed reduced yields either due to dehalogenation side reactions or incomplete conversions of starting materials. Despite attempts to optimize reaction conditions, completely eradicating side products proved challenging in the case of bromo and iodo derivatives. Subsequently, attention turned to nitrobenzene derivatives with various other substituents, including -NH2, -N, N-dimethyl, -OH, -SH, and -OCH3 groups, yielding between 84 % and over 91 % (Scheme 3 , entries 13–18). Moreover, heteroaromatic nitroarenes including o-nitropyridine, m-nitropyridine, p-nitropyridine, and 8-nitroquinoline demonstrated impressive product yields up to 91 % (Scheme 3 , entries 19–22). Polyaromatic nitro compounds such as 1-nitronaphthalene and 1-nitropyrene demonstrated complete selectivity and yields between 82 % and 85 % (Scheme 3 , entries 23–24). These findings highlight the method's remarkable efficiency and selectivity across a diverse spectrum of compounds, indicating its potential utility in various synthetic pathways. Any changes in the reaction conditions to get optimum yield are mentioned in Scheme 3. The corresponding 1H & 13C NMR and GCMS data are presented in the supplementary information (Fig. S7-S51). Our focus then shifted towards reducing nitro compounds containing sensitive functional groups such as ketones, carboxylic acids, amides, nitriles, olefins, and esters (Scheme 4) under optimized reaction conditions. We initiated our exploration with carbonyl compounds, particularly ketones (Scheme 4, entry 25). Interestingly, ketone (Scheme 4, entry 25) underwent smooth reactions without side products under typical conditions, yielding 81 % of the desired product under optimal conditions. Significantly, nitro derivatives containing carboxylic acid groups underwent seamless conversion into corresponding amines with exceptional outcomes of > 99 % selectivity & conversion, and product yield of up to 85 % (Scheme 4, entries 26–28). We then directed our attention to amide (Scheme 4, entry 29), which yielded 60 % under standard conditions due to less conversion of starting material under standard reaction conditions. Subsequently, we explored nitro compounds with -CN functional groups, and all tested compounds (Scheme 4, entries 30–32) yielded the desired products successfully, achieving a product yield between 88 % and 91 % and a selectivity of > 99 %, without the formation of any side products. However, converting compounds containing double bonds presented a significant challenge (Scheme 4, entries 33). Despite optimized conditions, side reactions occurred due to the susceptibility of double bonds to reduction alongside nitro groups. As a result, compound no. 33 yielded only 35 % of the desired product. Further, we examined nitro compounds containing N-amide and ester substitutions (Scheme 4, entries 34–36), which also exhibited a remarkable product yield without the formation of any undesired products. Benzocaine (Scheme 4, entry 36) is a well-known pharmaceutical compound that serves as a topical local anesthetic employed to provide temporary alleviation from pain and itching linked to minor burns, sunburn, scrapes, insect bites, or minor skin irritations[120]. In assessing the effectiveness of dynamic catalysts for advanced-stage functional group conversions, a study was conducted involving three distinct pharmaceutical compounds incorporating a -NO2 functional group, as outlined in Scheme 4. Among these compounds, Nimesulide[121], recognized as a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medication with analgesic and antipyretic properties, bears a sulfonamide group and an ether bridge in addition to the -NO2 moiety (Scheme 4, entry 37). This compound demonstrated a yield of 70 %. Nimodipine[122], a commonly used drug for calcium channel inhibition to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage, featuring a pyridine heterocycle core with two ester groups alongside the -NO2 moiety, smoothly underwent reduction of the -NO2 functional group, exhibiting complete selectivity with a conversion rate of > 99 % and a 66 % isolated yield under reoptimized reaction conditions (Scheme 4, entry 38). Flutamide[123], an anticancer nonsteroidal antiandrogen, which bears the sulphonamide group, yielded 87 % with complete selectivity (Scheme 4, entry 39). The 1H & 13C NMR and GCMS data for representative compounds are provided in the supporting information (Fig. S52-S75). 3.4 Gram-scale synthesis of pharma intermediates Encouraged by the promising results attained in converting various nitroarenes to their aryl amines using the innovative Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst, we embarked on an extensive exploration of its potential for synthesizing pharmaceutical intermediates on a larger scale, as depicted in Scheme 5. Our initial investigation involved transforming 4-(2-fluoro-4-nitrophenyl)morpholine into 3-fluoro-4-morpholinoaniline (Scheme 5, entry 40) on a one-gram scale. This compound serves as a crucial intermediate in synthesizing linezolid [124], an antibiotic effective against antibiotic-resistant gram-positive bacteria. Remarkably, this reaction proceeded smoothly, with an isolated yield of 87 % with complete conversion of the starting material. Then our endeavors encompassed the conversion of 2-chloro-1-fluoro-4-nitrobenzene into 3-chloro-4-fluoroaniline (Scheme 5, entry 41), a pivotal building block for the production of norfloxacin [125,126], an antibiotic used to treat urinary tract infections, gynecological infections, prostate gland inflammation, gonorrhea, and bladder infections. This molecule was achieved with a 70 % isolated yield. We observed a dehalogenation side reaction for this molecule. Continuing our exploration, we investigated the conversion of 1,2-bis(2-nitrophenyl)ethane into 2,2′-(ethane-1,2-diyl)dianiline (Scheme 5, entry 42), a crucial drug intermediate for Carbamazepine [127], a medication used to manage epilepsy, trigeminal neuralgia, and acute manic and mixed episodes in bipolar I disorder. Initially, under reoptimised reaction conditions, we achieved a yield of 66 % due to less conversion of starting material. However, we tried improving the product yield by employing elevated temperature (130°C) and 25 bar H2 over 36 h, but the attempt was unsuccessful. Furthermore, we synthesized 4-aminophenol from 4-nitrophenol under standard reaction conditions, yielded 91 % with > 99 % selectivity, and conversion (Scheme 5, entry 43). This compound is a significant drug intermediate in producing paracetamol [128], a medication for pain relief and fever reduction. Our investigation also encompassed the successful transformation of 4-chloro-1-methyl-2-nitrobenzene into 5-chloro-2-methylaniline using standard reaction conditions (Scheme 5, entry 44). This endeavor resulted in comparatively good selectivity, conversion, and a product yield of 73 % under reoptimised reaction conditions. Notably, 5-chloro-2-methylaniline is a crucial intermediate in the synthesis of Tizanidine [129], a drug used as a muscle relaxant. In summary, we have developed a robust methodology for synthesizing all 05 drug intermediates on a one-gram scale, demonstrating the potential of our novel catalysts for commercial applications, supported by the development of scalable protocols. The corresponding 1H & 13C NMR and GC-MS data are provided in the supporting information (Fig. S76-S84). 3.5 Catalyst stability and recyclability Recyclability and stability are essential traits of heterogeneous catalysts. To evaluate the stability of the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, we conducted hydrogenation reactions of 4-nitro anisole to 4-methoxy aniline over shorter reaction times (12 h). After the initial 12 h reaction, the conversion of 4-nitro anisole was found to be ∼60 %. Subsequent repeated runs showed no change in the conversion rate of 4-nitro anisole, confirming the stability of the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst under standard reaction conditions ( Fig. 7a). Furthermore, after 12 h of reaction, the catalyst was separated by hot filtration to assess stability. Then, 0.5 mmol of 4-nitro anisole was added to the filtrate, and the reaction continued for an additional 12 h and was evaluated. No further progress in the reaction was observed, indicating no leaching of bismuth particles into the reaction mixture during the reaction; otherwise, this could have promoted the reaction. Additionally, ICP-OES measurement confirmed the absence of bismuth nanoparticles in the filtrate, indicating the integrity of the bismuth particles on the catalyst surface throughout the reaction. Next, we evaluated the recyclability and reusability of the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the hydrogenation of 4-nitro anisole under optimized conditions, as shown in Fig. 7(b). The Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was separated by simple filtration, washed three times with ethyl acetate followed by ethanol solvent, and dried under vacuum at 60°C for 12 hours before being used in the next cycle. The Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated consistent performance over four cycles, with no noticeable decline in catalytic activity and selectivity. 3.6 Reaction mechanism Using standard reaction conditions by changing the reaction time, the reaction mechanism was established using nitrobenzene as a model substrate. Typically, the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline proceeds through either a direct or an indirect condensation route, following the established mechanisms proposed by Haber and Jackson [88,130–132]. These mechanisms involve the formation of various intermediates, including nitrosobenzene (NSB), N-phenylhydroxylamine (PHA), azoxybenzene (AOB), azobenzene (AB), and hydrazobenzene (HAB). These intermediates have been substantiated through extensive kinetic studies employing online Raman and IR spectroscopic techniques by different research groups. Our systematic investigation ( Fig. 8) aimed to elucidate the underlying reaction mechanism by tracking the generation of these intermediates at multiple time intervals (0.5 h, 1 h, 2 h, 3 h, 6 h, 12 h, and 24 h). We analyzed the reaction mixtures using gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector (GC FID) equipped with a capillary column (DB-5, 20 m). Initially, we established a GC FID chromatogram by employing standard substances such as NSB, PHA, AB, AOB, nitrobenzene (NB), and aniline (AN). Subsequently, we utilized the same analytical method to examine the reaction mixtures collected at each time point, which allowed us to identify the formation of these intermediates. Significantly, the initial reaction mixtures obtained at 0.5 h, 1 h, 2 h, and 3 h prominently featured the presence of nitrosobenzene, as depicted in Fig. S85-90. The 6 h reaction mixture exhibited the presence of NSB, NB, and AN at varying concentrations. We did not detect intermediates such as AOB, AB, or HAB, typically associated with the condensation mechanism. To further confirm the reaction mechanism, we conducted separate reactions involving NSB, PHA, AOB, and AB under optimized hydrogenation conditions employing an active bismuth catalyst (Fig. 8a-b and Table S6). Remarkably, we observed the successful formation of aniline from nitrosobenzene and mixed behavior with individual other standard compounds. Based on the reaction kinetics studies, we strongly support the likelihood that the predominant route for this reaction is the direct mechanism. 3.7 DFT calculation As previously explained, the reduction of nitrobenzene into aniline may occur through an established mechanism, illustrated in Fig. 9, encompassing either direct or indirect routes. A comprehensive dispersion-corrected DFT calculation was conducted to delineate the energetically favored path for nitrobenzene reduction on the Bi (202) catalyst surface. This analysis elucidated the changes in structures and energy associated with all potential elementary steps within the direct or indirect pathways of the intermediates on the Bismuth catalyst pertinent to the hydrogenation reaction. The geometry-optimized surface of Bi (202) is depicted in Fig. 9. 3.7.1 Adsorption of nitrobenzene (Ph-NO2) and Nitrosobenzene (Ph-NO) formation The pivotal step in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline involves the adsorption of nitrobenzene (Ph-NO2) onto the Bi (202) surface (Step 1). Fig. 10(a) shows a parallel adsorption mode of nitrobenzene on the Bi (202) surface, which released a free energy of −252.3 kJ mol−1. The distance between the 'N' and the nearest 'Bi' atom on the surface is determined to be 3.7 Å, with the two ‘N-O’ bond lengths calculated at approximately 1.25 Å each. (1) 2PhNO2(g) + 6H2(g) → PhNO2* + PhNO2(g) + 6H2(g) (2) PhNO2* + PhNO2(g) + 6H2(g) → PhNO* + H2O(g) + PhNO2(g) + 5H2 In the subsequent step (Step 2), an ‘H′ atom associates with Ph-NO2* to form Ph-NOOH*, followed by the cleavage of the N-OH bond in the second hydrogen transfer step, resulting in the formation of Ph-NO* and the release of a water molecule. This Ph-NO* intermediate, proposed by Haber in Fig. 8, has gained widespread acceptance, independent of the catalysts or hydrogen sources used. Fig. 10(b) illustrates an adsorption of Ph-NO* on the Bi (202) surface, where 'N-O′ bond is slightly elongated, with a measured length of 1.28 Å. This step is more exergonic by 36.3 kJ mol−1 than the adsorption of Ph-NO2* with a release in free energy of −394.8 kJ mol−1. 3.7.2 Aniline (Ph-NH2) formation (via direct pathway) In this section, the process of reducing nitrosobenzene to aniline through the hydroxylamine intermediate was explored, and the potential elementary steps are outlined below: (3) PhNO* + H2O(g) + PhNO2(g) + 5H2(g) → PhNHOH* + H2O (g) + PhNO2(g) + 4H2(g) (4) PhNHOH* + H2O(g) + PhNO2(g) + 4H2(g) → PhNH2* + 2H2O (g) + PhNO2(g) + 3H2(g) (5) PhNH2* + 2H2O(g) + PhNO2(g) + 3H2(g) → PhNH2* + 2H2O (g) + PhNO2* + 3H2 (g) (6) PhNH2* + 2H2O (g) + PhNO2* + 3H2 (g) → PhNH2* + 3H2O (g) + PhNO* + 2H2(g) (7) PhNH2* + 3H2O (g) + PhNO* + 2H2(g) → PhNH2* + 3H2O (g) + PhNHOH* +H2(g) (8) PhNH2* + 3H2O (g) + PhNHOH* + H2(g) → 2PhNH2* + 4H2O (g) In the initial step (step 3), two 'H' atoms were attached to the 'N' and 'O' atoms of Ph-NO* to create Ph-NHOH* intermediate, as illustrated in Fig. 10(c). The formation of Ph-NHOH* on the Bi (202) surface was determined to release a free energy of −362.7 kJ mol−1, signifying a greater exergonic nature compared to Ph-NO* by 74.2 kJ mol−1. The 'N-O′ bond length increased by 0.15 Å to 1.43 Å in this hydrogenation process. In the subsequent hydrogenation step (step 4), an 'H' atom is attached to the 'OH' group of Ph-NHOH*, leading to the elimination of an H2O molecule and finally the formation of Ph-NH2* (Fig. 10(d)). The free energy calculated for the for formation of Ph-NH2* from Ph-NHOH* was determined to be −645.0 kJ mol−1, which surpassed the exergonicity of Ph-NHOH* by 282.3 kJ mol−1. Prior to this, the aniline molecule got desorbed, and a second nitrobenzene was considered to undergo reduction to aniline in the same fashion on another periodic Bi (202) surface for a comparison study with the indirect pathways, as shown in step (5). The adsorption of Ph-NO2*, in conjunction with Ph-NH2*, was found to be highly exergonic with a calculated free energy of −897.2 kJ mol−1. This Ph-NO2* further transformed into nitrosobenzene (Ph-NO*) in the presence of H2 through dehydration (step 6), releasing a free energy of −933.5 kJ mol−1. The Ph-NO* intermediate subsequently underwent successive hydrogenation, forming the Ph-NHOH* intermediate (step 7) releasing a free energy of −1007.7 kJ mol−1. Further, Ph-NHOH* hydrogenated to aniline (Ph-NH2*), expelling an H2O molecule (step 8). The free energy for the adsorption of two Ph-NH2* molecules on the Bi (202) surface was calculated to be −1290.1 kJ mol−1. 3.7.3 Aniline (Ph-NH2) formation (via indirect pathway) The reduction of nitrobenzene (Ph-NO2) can alternatively advance through the azobenzene intermediate, culminating in the final product, aniline (Ph-NH2), denoted as the indirect pathway. Each potential elementary step was examined to clarify the energy changes associated with this indirect pathway. (9) PhNO* + H2O(g) + PhNO2(g) + 5H2(g) → PhNHOH* + H2O (g) + PhNO2* + 4H2(g) (10) PhNHOH* + H2O(g) + PhNO2* + 4H2(g) → PhNHOH* + 2H2O (g) + PhNO* + 3H2(g) (11) PhNHOH* + 2H2O (g) + PhNO* + 3H2(g) → PhN-NO-Ph* + 3H2O (g) + 3H2 (g) (12) PhN-NO-Ph* + 3H2O (g) + 3H2 (g) → PhN=N-Ph* + 4H2O (g) + 2H2 (g) (13) PhN=N-Ph* + 4H2O (g) + 2H2 (g) → PhNH-HN-Ph* + 4H2O (g) + H2 (g) (14) PhNH-HN-Ph* + 4H2O (g) + H2 (g) → 2PhNH2* + 4H2O (g) The initial step involves the co-adsorption of Ph-NHOH* and Ph-NO2* on the Bi (202) surface, leading to the formation of azoxybenzene (Ph-N-NO-Ph*) (step 9). Fig. 11(a) depicted the co-adsorption of Ph-NHOH* and Ph-NO2* on the Bi (202) surface, with an associated free energy of −615.0 kJ mol−1. The interatomic distance between the 'N' of Ph-NHOH* and the 'N' of Ph-NO* was measured at 3.49 Å. In the subsequent step (step 10), the adsorbed Ph-NO2* undergoes hydrogenation to produce nitrosobenzene (Ph-NO*). A calculated free energy of −651.2 kJ mol−1 was released during this process, which was highly exergonic by 36.2 kJ mol−1 than the previous step. Interestingly, the interatomic distance between both 'N' was observed to be decreased to 2.79 Å, indicating a favorable possibility of the formation of azoxybenzene (Ph-N-NO-Ph*). Further in the sequence, the interaction between nitrosobenzene (Ph-NO*) and phenylhydroxylamine (Ph-NHOH*) resulted in the formation of azoxybenzene (Ph-N-NO-Ph*) (step 11), accompanied by the release of water. Ph-N-NO-Ph* was found to be adsorbed on the Bi (202) surface (Fig. 11(c)), and this step releases a computed free energy of −685.7 kJ mol−1. The ‘N-N’ bond length was determined to be −1.29 Å. Subsequently in step 12, azobenzene (Ph-N = N-Ph*) was formed from azoxybenzene (Ph-N-NO-Ph*), showing adsorption on the Bi (202) surface (Fig. 11(d)) with a reaction energy of −1039.2 kJ mol−1, which is 118.2 kJ mol−1 more exothermic compared to the adsorption of Ph-N-NO-Ph*. The formation of Ph-N = N-Ph* from Ph-N-NO-Ph* released computed free energy of −781.3 kJ mol−1, and a slight decrease in the N-N bond was observed, attributed to the increase in bond order with the dehydration step. This Ph-N = N-Ph* was further hydrogenated to hydrazo-benzene (Ph-NH-HN-Ph*) (step 13), and Fig. 11(e) illustrates the adsorption of Ph-NH-HN-Ph* on Bi (202) surface. This step was calculated to be highly exergonic with a release in free energy of −815.9 kJ mol−1, and the 'N-N′ bond length was measured to be 1.45 Å, elongated by 0.18 Å compared to azobenzene (1.27 Å) due to the reduction in bond order. Finally, Ph-NH-HN-Ph* was dissociated to aniline (Ph-NH2) through stepwise hydrogenation and cleavage of the azo (N-N) bond, exhibiting a release in the free energy of −1289.9 kJ mol−1. 3.7.4 Desorption of aniline from the Bi (202) surface In this step (step 15), one of the aniline molecules produced from both direct and indirect pathways got desorbed from the Bi (202) surface to give a gas phase aniline molecule. This desorption step released a free energy of −914.1 kJ mol−1 and was found to be endergonic by 375.8 kJ mol−1. After the desorption of the first aniline molecule, in the final step (step 16), the second molecules also got desorbed with a computed free energy of −538.1 kJ mol−1, which was even more endergonic by 376.0 kJ mol−1. (15) 2PhNH2* + 4H2O (g) → PhNH2* + PhNH2 (g) + 4H2O (g) (16) PhNH2* + PhNH2 (g) + 4H2O (g) → 2PhNH2(g) + 4H2O (g) Fig. 12 illustrates the free energy profiles released with various intermediates in direct and indirect pathways, offering valuable insights into the preferred routes followed during the reduction of nitrobenzene to aniline. A comparison analysis between step 4 and step 9 revealed that the co-adsorption of Ph-NHOH* with Ph-NO2* was energetically more favorable than the adsorption of Ph-NHOH*. However, in the case of the formation of azoxybenzene in step 11, it was observed that the condensation of Ph-NHOH* with Ph-NO* to form Ph-N-NO-Ph was less energetically favorable than the adsorption of second Ph-NO2* (Step 6). Furthermore, in the subsequent steps, it became evident that the further hydrogenation of the second Ph-NO2* to Ph-NH2* is more energetically favorable, releasing higher free energies than the hydrogenation of Ph-N-NO-Ph* to Ph-NH2*. Therefore, it can be inferred that Ph-NO2 is hydrogenated to Ph-NH2 through the direct pathways due to the more favorable energetics in these elementary steps, which was in good agreement with the experimental findings. 4 Conclusions In summary, we developed an eco-friendly and reusable heterogeneous Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by simple impregnation followed by pyrolysis. The active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated exceptional activity and selectivity for the reduction of nitro (-NO2) groups across a wide range of nitroarenes (36 diverse molecules), enabling 03 late-stage functional group transformations. In terms of commercial feasibility, the utility of the catalyst has been established through the synthesis of various pharmaceutical intermediates such as 3-fluoro-4-morpholinoaniline, 3-chloro-4-fluoroaniline, 2,2′-(ethane-1,2-diyl)dianiline, 4-aminophenol, 4-chlorobenzene-1,2-diamine and 2,6-dichloroaniline on a ∼1 g scale, with the product yields reaching up to 99 %. The characterization results reveal that bismuth co-exists in zero and + 3 oxidation states in the active Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and the direct interaction between nitrogen atoms and bismuth particles, enhancing the catalyst's stability. The catalyst screening results and physicochemical properties of Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst suggest that the remarkable activity and selectivity of Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is due to the presence of bismuth in its zero oxidation state (Bi(0)), acidic properties and the interaction between nitrogen atoms and bismuth particles. The stability and reusability of the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 nanocatalyst have been convincingly demonstrated, with no noticeable loss of activity or selectivity over four catalytic cycles. Systematic studies using analytical techniques established a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism. Additionally, Density Functional Theory studies have enriched our comprehension of the catalytic process and direct mechanism. In summary, this study has made a significant contribution to the field of catalysis by introducing a sustainable and efficient methodology using bismuth catalysts using molecular hydrogen. It underscores the immense potential of bismuth catalysts in revolutionizing pharmaceutical and chemical synthesis, offering academic insights and practical solutions for environmentally conscious and commercially viable processes. coredata.dc:description: Bismuth is renowned for its exceptional safety, highlighted by numerous examples demonstrating its low toxicity. Considering this, we present a novel, active, and reusable heterogeneous bismuth catalyst (Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3) for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to aryl amines using molecular hydrogen. The Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized through a simple impregnation method followed by pyrolysis at 700°C, for 2 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The physicochemical properties of fresh and spent Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were comprehensively characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The bismuth content in the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was estimated by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance and selectivity in reducing a wide variety of nitroarenes to their corresponding aryl amines, achieving good to excellent yields (36 examples). Furthermore, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was applied to the selective hydrogenation of nitro groups in three commercially available drugs. Additionally, five pharmaceutical intermediates, including linezolid, Norfloxacin, Carbamazepine, paracetamol, and tizanidine, were synthesized up to a ∼1 g scale with a quantitative yield, showcasing the catalyst activity and selectivity. Further, the reaction mechanism was elucidated by tracking the intermediates (through GC-FID & GC-MS) and employing Density Functional Theory (DFT). Notably, the Bi-NC/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is stable, recovered, and reused for four cycles without losing significant activity and selectivity.
